sense.name: a set of similar things taken together
sense.examples: John brought a pack of cards on the plane. Mary broke open a pack of gum and offered it around. How much does a pack of cigarettes cost these days?

sense.name: a social clique of people
sense.examples: He got involved with a pack of drug dealers. Mary says they are a snooty little pack of housewives from the country club. Little Johnny is part of the neighborhood brat pack. Their sons are in the same Cub Scout pack.

sense.name: an organized band of hunting animals
sense.examples: The big gray one is the alpha male in the wolf pack. A pack of hyenas cautiously approached the lioness as she fed on the carcass. Packs of stray dogs roamed the streets after the big earthquake.

sense.name: an approximate large quantity, multitude
sense.examples: The celebrity said the stories were nothing but a pack of lies. Packs of teenagers stood in front of the theater, hoping to glimpse the rock star. Packs and packs of ice lay ahead in the cold waters off the northern Alaskan coastline.

sense.name: a knapsack, bundle on the back
sense.examples: The hikers each carried a sixty-pound pack up the mountain trail. Mary wore a fanny back on the sightseeing excursions. The peddler carried all sorts of wares in his large pack.

sense.name: a facial masque
sense.examples: Mary had a mud pack applied to her face at the day spa. The beautician applied a cream pack to the client's face.

sense.name: a therapeutic compress
sense.examples: Bob applied a cold pack to his swollen ankle. A hot, aromatic pack felt soothing against the patient's forehead. The dentist applied a medicated pack to the sutured area in the patient's mouth.

sense.name: a group of competitors
sense.examples: Their candidate finally broke away from the pack of contenders for the nomination. The black horse charged up from the back of the pack to win the race by a nose.
